BE11:20am

Key issue is that pricing has increased by 3x inflation over the last decade. The CMA is concerned about price visibility and customer choice at a time of distress. The CMA calls out the larger chains as being most at fault and states that ‘A number of these have now introduced lower cost funeral options, but this doesn’t go far enough to make up for years of above inflation price hikes’.

FATDAZ @Tom D Mrs Daz had looked at some flights to Rome for later in the year I had to let her down gently and tell her that out side of RYa I doubted that many of the lows cost option would be in business in the Autumn
BE11:21am

In addition to the review of funerals and cremations, the CMA also looked at including burials and pre-paid plans.
The view on burials was that they should not be included in the scope of the CMA as cemeteries in aggregate lose money (55 out of 73 local authorities are loss making), so a market related package would not be beneficial. The CMA concurs with the Institute of Cemetery and Crematorium Management view
that “the only logical means of halting rises in cemetery fees is to bring forward legislation for the reuse of old abandoned graves.” The CMA believes that issues relating to burials can be addressed as part of the package of services provided by funeral directors within the terms of reference.
The CMA has expanded the proposed terms of reference to include the
services supplied by funeral directors at the point of need from the
redemption of pre-paid funeral plans. The previous view was to exclude
them due to the HMT review. It appears HMT will retain control of the
review of marketing and sale of plans, with the CMA looking at their use at
point of need. The CMA highlights that c200,000 plans are sold per annum and account for c15% of funerals. The importance for Dignity is greater (given its national coverage) as funeral plans account for c27% of funerals.

BE11:29am

While the UK political outlook with regards to the current government and
Brexit plans remain fluid and the likelihood of a general election in the UK cannot be dismissed, we see many difficulties with such plan to renationalise.
First, to point out the obvious – National Grid is comprised of c.50% US assets. How exactly any UK government could take into public ownership a US asset is a key question. If anything, one can argue that the UK water utilities, 100% UK based are more exposed to any nationalisation plans.
Secondly, the Labour Party’s support has weakened in the last few months.
According to the latest YouGov/The Times polls, Labour has slipped to 33% from close to 40% at the beginning of this year. In the scenario of a general election, it’s not obvious that we will have a majority party winner, which means the potential for a coalition government. If Labour were in that coalition and depending on its partner, we could see a watering down of some of its policies outlined in its last election manifesto, including nationalisation of utilities.
Thirdly, how exactly would any government would set the price to renationalise remain uncertain.

Flaneur @Tom - yes, I think so.

We believe that growth will come through faster from Europe
than the US in the short-term. We do not think that this will fully offset
a slowdown in UK growth but considering the shares' de-rating over the
last six months, we do not think it needs to. We reiterate Outperform and
our price target increases marginally to £35 from £34.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE it's coming. If you think of the limited reach of Fevertree global, the price is toppy at the very least, but it'll be taken out.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

We highlighted on the day of results that Fever-Tree's FY19 performance
update "the Group is trading in line with Board expectations" was less
upbeat than it has been for the past two years: "we have had an
encouraging start". We don't want to read too much into Fevertree's
choice of wording however given its high valuation is dependent on
growth expectations we think it should be taken into account. We forecast
slightly better organic revenue growth in 2H19 than in 1H.
Europe has been given "the centre of attention that we think it deserves"
according to management at the results meeting. It is seeing strong
growth in numerous markets, similar fundamentals to the UK before
its peak and more spirits companies are embracing the long-drink
opportunity there. We increase our FY19E organic growth forecasts for
Europe from 23% to 30%. In addition, Fever-Tree's outlook for Europe of
"confidence as we move into 2019" indicates that growth is more likely
to come through there in the short-term than in the US where Fever-
Tree is "confident about the medium to longer term opportunity". It did
achieve 24% organic growth in the US despite 2018 being a transition year.
However we think the ramp up in the US will continue to be slower than
it was for the UK due to the size and diversity of the region and the need
to develop brand recognition.
We remain confident that Fever-Tree is expanding effectively in the US
and Europe and that organic revenue growth from these regions will partly
offset a slowdown in the UK. It will not be fully offset, however it does not
need to be. Our forecasts are conservative in our opinion and still result
in an APV-derived price target of £35. In addition, there has been some
relief in the share price post results however Fever-Tree's valuation still
looks considerably more attractive than before. It trades on 35x 2020E P/
E compared to around 60x at its peak in summer FY18.

We thought that 2018 results would have allayed many of the market’s concerns around downside to guidance, cash conversion / receivables drag, delays to the closing of the GOSI deal, and organic growth (see NMC Health - Something for everyone - we think net positive). From here, we think NMC bears will still focus on related-party transactions, modelling forecast risks, macro headwinds in the UAE, re-imbursement risks in the Basic scheme and the 19m shares pledged by Mr Khalifa Bin Butti (7% of outstanding; the share price was £28.50 around the time this was announced).

BE11:49am

Fielding numerous incoming calls on yesterday’s share price decline of c.7% on no news (FTSE flat), it was clear that the price action left investors scratching their heads. Since results on the 7th of March, NMC shares are down 27% (FTSE100 flat) amounting to loss of c.$2.3bn of market capitalization. Investor feedback on underlying fundamentals has been positive post results with pushback centered largely around communication (interest driven earnings miss and higher capex) which some expect to be fixed with the introduction of earnings guidance (as alluded to at our recent conference, see: Conference feedback, 13 Mar). Many investors we speak to consider the stock to be very attractive at these levels. With the short base at c.13%, up c.30% MoM, and the stock de-rating to the lowest valuation in over three years, we see fear around the investment case and the disconnect between fundamentals and valuation to be at their highest in some time. Overall, we believe that recent results were encouraging (see FY 18 results: Fears allayed, 7 Mar), that accounting concerns are misplaced (see our deep-dive report in conjunction with our accounting team: Healthier than you think, 4 Mar) and that this presents an attractive buying opportunity. At 15x 19E PE, valuation does not sufficiently reflect a 31% 17-21E EPS CAGR where growth is amongst the most visible in our sector. Catalysts include raising guidance to account for the CARE JV and Boston IVF, which we expect in the coming weeks. We are 7% ahead of consensus 2019E EBITDA. We continue to like the shares of NMC Health, which is our Top Pick in European MedTech & Services.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Following a robust year of operational delivery where gross
Shaikan production averaged 31.5Mbbl/d (PHe 31.5Mbbl/d)
and as the oil price recovered, GKP delivered a year of record
financial performance. Regular sales receipts generated revenue
and PAT of $250m/$80m (PHe $235m/$82m) which enabled
the balance to continue strengthening with YE18 net cash
building to $196m (PHe $197m) from c$60m YE17. As a result,
GKP is very well capitalised to fund both FY19 gross capex of
$150-$195m which will increase Shaikan production to
c55Mbbl/d by Q1 2020, as well as return cash to shareholders
via payment of a cash dividend. GKP has committed to
returning no less than $25m/pa (c3.25% yield) on an annual
basis and, owing to their current very strong financial position
will also pay a further $25m by way of a special dividend in
2019, giving a total FY19 yield of 6.5%.

BE11:55am

And Canaccord.

BE11:56am

Over the past couple of years Gulf Keystone has delivered very strong performance from the company's operated field, Shaikan, in KRI, which has translated to impressive free cash flow generation. We believe that all-round operational and financial delivery has provided the foundation for the next step up in production.

Over the next 12 months production is expected to grow by 70% through investment that is entirely, and comfortably, supported by the strength of the balance sheet. That has also allowed the company to begin dividend payments with a total of $50m to be paid in 2019, an attractive 6.5% yield. Ongoing, that is expected to be $25m per year.

We think this is a very appealing combination and in our view the gap between our (still cautious) NPV15 valuation of 337 p/sh and the market remains substantial despite the recent strong market performance. At lower discount rates, which we think are increasingly supportable, the upside is compelling. For example, at NPV10, our valuation rises to 433 p/sh.

Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 808.00, down 8.5 (-1.04%), High: 818.50, Low: 786.00, Volume: 146.53k
BE12:06pm

We initiate coverage of Metro Bank Plc at UW, 650p PT, with earnings estimates substantially below the Street.Wesee risks around further equity injections given weak profits/high growth, and appearmore cautious than the Street on rising funding costs.We analysepotential capital levers, although see this aslow probability.Despite share price -c.50% YTD, Metro is not cheap at c18x 2021E EPS, or 0.8x TNAV for 3-4% RoTE. We prefer OW-rated UK large caps Lloyds and RBS. We see fourkey debates:1.How much of a headwindis MREL?We think it is simply too expensive for Metro to issue in the current market. Following detailed work on potential issuance costs, we have earnings estimates c. 50% below consensusonlower net interest income.2.Is thereappetite for ongoingequity injections?We forecast 3-4% RoTE through to 2021 driven by weak NIM/high costs, which looksincompatible withMetro’stargeted20%pa growthwithout ongoingsupport.As well as an impending£350m equity raise, wethink Metro will seek to raise equity again in 2020.3.Is there a way for Metro notto raise?Ouranalysis suggestsMetro couldboost CET1 up to 300bps ifit soldpreviously misclassified assetsat book value (to a non-bank, say), although getting a ‘good’ price might be tricky.This could avoid a 2020 equity raise, but we estimate it could take c.10-15% offearnings.4.Could Metro moderategrowth further?Margin pressures may require a brake on growth. However, this potentially sits at odds with the company’s growth commitmentsmadeunder the £120m Capability and Innovation Fund bid.
